abstract: Wall Street and the federal government faced off over the weekend, raising worries of a sell-off when markets open on Monday.
snippet: Wall Street and the federal government faced off over the weekend, raising worries of a sell-off when markets open on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Wall Street and the federal government played a game of chicken over the weekend, and neither side backed down, pushing Lehman Brothers toward bankruptcy and setting off worries of a worldwide sell-off when markets open on Monday.

byline.original: By Floyd Norris and Vikas Bajaj

abstract: With its plan to buy Merrill Lynch, Bank of America is adding the most recognized name on Wall Street — and Merrill’s “Thundering Herd” of 17,000 brokers — to its empire.
snippet: With its plan to buy Merrill Lynch, Bank of America is adding the most recognized name on Wall Street — and Merrill’s “Thundering Herd” of 17,000 brokers — to its empire.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America’s dream of dominating the brokerage business always seemed to elude it, even after it transformed itself from a regional bank into a consumer banking powerhouse through two decades of big acquisitions.

headline.main: Purchase of Merrill Fulfills Quest for a Bank
headline.print_headline: Purchase Of Merrill Fulfills Quest For a Bank

abstract: It’s the end of an era for Merrill Lynch, the brokerage firm that brought Wall Street to Main Street.
snippet: It’s the end of an era for Merrill Lynch, the brokerage firm that brought Wall Street to Main Street.
lead_paragraph: It is the end of an era for Merrill Lynch, the brokerage firm that brought Wall Street to Main Street.

headline.main: Stunning Fall for Main Street’s Brokerage Firm
headline.print_headline: Stunning Fall for Main Street’s Brokerage Firm

abstract: Many momentous events transpired this weekend: the likely collapse of Lehman Brothers, the impending purchase of Merrill Lynch by Bank of America and the apparent failure of American International Group to raise enough money to stave off a credit rating upgrade.
lead_paragraph: Many momentous events transpired this weekend: the likely collapse of Lehman Brothers, the impending purchase of Merrill Lynch by Bank of America and the apparent failure of American International Group to raise enough money to stave off a credit rating upgrade.

headline.main: Banks Lost Fight to Halt Bets Against Financial Firms

abstract: The move indicated that officials have grave concerns about future losses at banks beyond Lehman.
snippet: The move indicated that officials have grave concerns about future losses at banks beyond Lehman.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Even though the Federal Reserve refused to provide a financial backstop to potential buyers of Lehman Brothers, concerns over what may unfold in the market on Monday led it to dramatically loosen its standards on making emergency loans to major Wall Street investment banks.

headline.main: Fed Loosens Standards on Emergency Loans
headline.print_headline: Federal Reserve Offers No Cash but Loosens Standards on Emergency Loans

abstract: In one of the most dramatic days in Wall Street’s history, Merrill Lynch agreed to sell itself on Sunday to Bank of America for roughly $50 billion to avert a deepening financial crisis, while another prominent securities firm, Lehman Brothers, said it would seek bankruptcy protection and hurtled toward liquidation after it failed to find a buyer.
lead_paragraph: In one of the most dramatic days in Wall Street’s history, Merrill Lynch agreed to sell itself on Sunday to Bank of America for roughly $50 billion to avert a deepening financial crisis, while another prominent securities firm, Lehman Brothers, said it would seek bankruptcy protection and hurtled toward liquidation after it failed to find a buyer.

headline.main: Lehman in Bankruptcy; Merrill to Be Sold; A.I.G. Struggles

abstract: CNBC interviews Kenneth D. Lewis, chairman of Bank of America, on the strategy behind the deal for Merrill Lynch.
snippet: CNBC interviews Kenneth D. Lewis, chairman of Bank of America, on the strategy behind the deal for Merrill Lynch.
lead_paragraph: CNBC interviews Kenneth D. Lewis, chairman of Bank of America, on the strategy behind the deal for Merrill Lynch.

headline.main: Bank of America Chief Discusses Deal

abstract: Bank of America is getting a lot of assets in its $50 billion acquisition of Merrill Lynch. In a normal deal, the two firms would already be presenting hundreds of glossy slides and reams of reports showing how the combined firm would stack up against the competition. But Merrill and Bank of America entered merger talks only Saturday night, so the information streaming out Monday left much to be desired.
lead_paragraph: Bank of America is getting a lot of assets in its $50 billion acquisition of Merrill Lynch. In a normal deal, the two firms would already be presenting hundreds of glossy slides and reams of reports showing how the combined firm would stack up against the competition. But Merrill and Bank of America entered merger talks only Saturday night, so the information streaming out Monday left much to be desired.

abstract: Merrill Lynch shares closed today at $17.06, up all of one cent since Bank of America agreed to buy the company for stock supposed to be worth $29.
lead_paragraph: Merrill Lynch shares closed today at $17.06, up all of one cent since Bank of America agreed to buy the company for stock supposed to be worth $29.
